types

namespace types

Vector

template<typename T> struct Vector

Vector is a container that holds a list of elements simillarily to an array, but it’s generic, can be easily manipulated (resized, appended etc.) and its memory is managed automatically.

Summary
Variables
MIN_SIZEThe minimal amount of elements to reserve space for when creating the buffer.

Variables

MIN_SIZE

enum { MIN_SIZE = 8 }

The minimal amount of elements to reserve space for when creating the buffer.

Types

it

Iterator typedef, a T*.

cit

Const iterator typedef, a const T*.

rit

Reverse iterator typedef, a <Reverse> < it >.

vrit

Const reverse iterator typedef, a <Reverse> < cit >.

Functions

Vector

Vector(): p_buf(NULL), p_length(0), p_capacity(0)

Constructs an empty vector.

Vector

Vector(const Vector &v): p_buf(NULL), p_length(0), p_capacity(0)

Constructs a vector from another vector.

Vector

Vector(size_t sz,  
const T &v =  T()): Vector()

Constructs a vector of a given size.  Optional element given by the second argument will be repeated in it.

Vector

~Vector()

Calls clear.

=

Vector& operator=(const Vector &v)

Assignment operator for the vector.  It makes this vector take parameters of the given vector.

Buffer is not simply assigned, instead, a new one is allocated and the elements are inserted inside it.

This makes heavy use of copy constructors.

begin

it begin()

Returns a pointer to the buffer.

begin

cit begin() const

Returns a const pointer to the buffer.

rbegin

rit rbegin()

Returns a <reverse> iterator to end.

rbegin

crit rbegin() const

Returns a const <reverse> iterator to end.

end

it end()

Returns a pointer to the element after the last one.

end

cit end() const

Returns a const pointer to the element after the last one.

rend

rit rend()

Returns a <reverse> iterator to begin.

rend

crit rend() const

Returns a const <reverse> iterator to begin.

get_buf

T *get_buf()

Returns the internal buffer.

get_buf

const T *get_buf() const

Returns the internal buffer as const.

resize

void resize(size_t sz,  
const T &v =  T())

Resizes the vector to be of given size.  If the capacity is too small for that, it calls reserve with the size first.

Second optional argument provides data that can be copied into each field that was initialized this time (happens when the given size is greater than the old size).

length

size_t length() const

Returns the current vector length.

capacity

size_t capacity() const

Returns the current vector capacity.

is_empty

bool is_empty() const

Returns true if the vector is empty, false otherwise.

reserve

void reserve(size_t sz)

Reserves the size given by the argument.  If that is smaller (or equal) than current capacity, this will do nothing.  If it’s bigger, the buffer will be reallocated.

[]

T& operator[](size_t idx)

Returns a reference to the field on the given index.  Used for assignment.

[]

const T& operator[](size_t idx) const

Returns a const reference to the field on the given index.  Used for reading.

at

T& at(size_t idx)

Returns a reference to the field on the given index.  Used for assignment.

at

const T& at(size_t idx) const

Returns a const reference to the field on the given index.  Used for reading.

push_back

T& push_back(const T &data =  T())

Appends a given value to the end of the vector.  If the current capacity is not big enough to hold the future contents, it’ll be resized.

This returns a reference to the newly added element.

pop_back

void pop_back()

Pops a last value out of the vector.

clear

void clear()

Clears the vector contents.  Deletes the buffer and sets the length and capacity to 0.

As the buffer is initialized as uchar*, it also calls a destructor for each value inside the buffer.
